fixerProfile.title: Faraday
fixerProfile.specialization: Corporate Espionage, Prototype Acquisition, Black Ops, Asset Denial

biography.earlyLife: Faraday was a product of the Militech corporate machine. A junior executive in the R&D acquisitions department, he was known for his cold ambition and a complete lack of empathy. He saw the chaotic underworld of Night City not as a danger, but as an untapped resource—a way to climb the corporate ladder by using deniable assets (mercs) to achieve off-the-books objectives for his superiors.
biography.riseAsFixer: He never operated like a traditional fixer. He was an internal corporate agent given a long leash. Militech provided him with access to cutting-edge prototypes and a hefty budget to run black ops against Arasaka. He built a reputation for having the shiniest new chrome and the biggest payouts, which attracted skilled but desperate crews like the one led by Maine, and later, David Martinez.
biography.modusOperandi: Faraday's method was simple: dangle an irresistible prize—a piece of military-grade tech or a life-changing sum of eddies—and push his crew to their absolute limits. He was a micromanager, demanding constant updates and showing no tolerance for failure. He viewed his mercs not as people, but as investments. If an investment went bad, he would cut his losses without a moment's hesitation, often by selling out the crew to save himself.
biography.reputation: Faraday is remembered as a cautionary tale about the dangers of corpo gigs. He was a user, a man who burned through one of the most promising crews in Santo Domingo to fuel his own career. To veteran mercs, his name is a byword for betrayal. Working for him was a fast track to either a penthouse or a shallow grave, with the odds heavily favouring the latter.

legendaryGig.objective: Steal the Zetatech 'Kestrel' prototype, an experimental combat hovercar, directly from its exhibition lap during the annual Night City Grand Prix.
legendaryGig.outcome: A spectacular and violent success. Faraday provided Maine's crew with a Militech Basilisk APC equipped with a prototype EMP cannon. They used it to disable the Kestrel mid-race, leading to a massive pile-up and a running battle with Zetatech security on the Grand Prix track itself. The crew successfully hijacked the prototype and escaped through the storm drains, leaving a trail of destruction. Militech got their prize, and Faraday got his promotion.
legendaryGig.mercFeedback: 'Faraday gave us a fucking tank and told us to crash a party. It was chaos. We almost bought it a dozen times, but the chrome was top-shelf, and the payout... Jesus. With that kind of gear, you feel like you can do anything. That's the hook. He makes you feel invincible right before he gets you killed.' - 'Maine' (Crew Leader)
legendaryGig.payout: €$ 400,000 + Rights to keep the (heavily damaged) EMP cannon.
legendaryGig.reputationImpact: This heist defined Faraday's modus operandi. It proved he could provide mercs with military-grade hardware for high-risk, high-reward operations. It cemented his reputation as the fixer who offered the best toys and the biggest paychecks, attracting ambitious, chrome-hungry crews and establishing his pattern of using them as live-fire test subjects for Militech's newest weapons.

fixerRatings.reliability: 2/10 - Highly Unstable. He honors the payment if a job is a clean success, but will immediately betray his crew to corporate forces to cover his tracks or mitigate failure.
fixerRatings.payment: 9/10 - Backed by Militech's deep pockets, his payouts were among the highest in the city, a necessary lure for the extreme risks involved.
fixerRatings.intelQuality: 7/10 - Provides excellent corporate-level data, but often overlooks or ignores on-the-ground human factors, leading to deadly surprises.
fixerRatings.discretion: 4/10 - His operations are flashy and tend to attract massive heat. He is skilled at erasing his own connection, but leaves his mercs to take the fall.
fixerRatings.resourcefulness: 9/10 - His primary advantage. Can source military-grade prototypes and experimental cyberware that no other fixer can get.
fixerRatings.mercSurvivability: 1/10 - Abysmal. Working for Faraday was a near-certain death sentence. His crews had one of the shortest life expectancies in the business.

strengths: Unprecedented access to Militech's experimental and military-grade technology.
Offers exceptionally high payouts for successful missions.
Ambitious, high-stakes gigs that could make a merc a legend.
Direct line to a major corporation's resources.
weaknesses: Views mercenaries as completely disposable assets.
High probability of betrayal at the first sign of trouble.
Gigs are extremely dangerous and often pit crews against Arasaka's elite forces.
Lack of street-level common sense in his planning.

recentGigDetails.objective: Field-test and secure the Militech 'Cyberskeleton' prototype by eliminating Arasaka forces during a high-profile corporate confrontation.
recentGigDetails.outcome: Catastrophic Failure. The operative, David Martinez, successfully utilized the Cyberskeleton but suffered a full-blown cyberpsychotic breakdown. The resulting rampage through City Center triggered a maximum-level MAX-TAC response. Faraday attempted to flee but was ultimately eliminated by Militech's own internal affairs agents for his failure to control the asset.
recentGigDetails.mercFeedback: 'Log Analysis: Faraday pushed the operative past all known human limits for a piece of hardware. When the asset went rogue, Faraday's only protocol was self-preservation. A complete operational and ethical failure.' - Post-Incident Report

recentGigDetails.objective: Intercept an Arasaka limo and forcibly extract navigational data from corporate executive Kenichi Tanaka.
recentGigDetails.outcome: Partially Successful with Severe Complications. The crew successfully stopped the limo, but the operation devolved into a chaotic firefight, resulting in Tanaka's death. The data was retrieved, but the unsanctioned killing of a high-level Arasaka exec put immense heat on the crew and made them a priority target for corporate retaliation.
recentGigDetails.mercFeedback: 'The job went sideways fast. It was supposed to be a snatch and grab, but it turned into a murder. Faraday didn't care how it got done, only that he got his data. That's when the real trouble started.' - Crew Survivor Testimony

recentGigDetails.objective: Acquire sensitive information from a rival Arasaka netrunner, Maxim Kuznetsov, regarding Arasaka's deep-net security protocols.
recentGigDetails.outcome: Successful. The crew, led by Maine, cornered the target and forcibly extracted the required data. The operation was clean by Faraday's standards, reinforcing his trust in the crew for more high-stakes operations.
recentGigDetails.mercFeedback: 'Standard corpo-on-corpo shit. Faraday pointed, we bit. The pay was good, so we didn't ask too many questions. Maybe we should have.' - Maine (Crew Leader)
